Situation A. Tevy and Santo Strategies for Determining Outcomes

  • Compare Santo and Tevy’s methods for finding all the outcomes for the sample space.

SOLUTION BEGIN

Both strategies are an organized way to find the same sample space.

Tevy considered all three coins at one time.

Santo considered the possible result of tossing each coin, then combined the results to get the outcomes.

Situation B. Possible or Probable?

Santo and Tevy were analyzing the probabilities of the Match, No-Match game and came up with the following comments.

What do you think each person meant?

Santo and Tevy’s Conversation

Santo said, “It is possible to toss three coins and have them match.”

Tevy replied, “Yes, but is it probable?”

SOLUTION BEGIN

Santo means that all three coins match sometimes. Mathematically, this means the probability of all three coins matching is greater than zero.

Tevy wants Santo to consider that the probability of all coins matching is greater than zero, or possible. However, the theoretical probability of it happening is small, it is not probable. The probability that all three coins will not match is greater than the probability that they will.

Situation C. Winning the Bonus Prize for Gee Whiz Everyone Wins!

Brelynn and Akimi make up a new game. All the winners from the Gee Whiz Everyone Wins! game show have the opportunity to compete for a bonus prize. There are two bags.

  • Each bag contains one red, one yellow, and one blue block.
  • The person will pick one block from each bag.
  • The person must predict the color they will pick from each bag.
  • If the prediction is correct, they win a bonus prize!
• List all the possible color pairs that can be chosen. Are the outcomes equally likely? Explain your reasoning.
SOLUTION BEGIN
There are nine possible outcomes: RR, RY, RB, YR, YY, YB, BR, BY, and BB

tiles.title: Tree Diagram for Choosing Two Blocks

text:
All pairs are equally likely because there is exactly one of each color block in each of the bags and order matters in this game, so RY is different from YR.

If order did not matter, the outcomes would not be equally likely.
SOLUTION END
• Find the theoretical probability of choosing each pair of colors.

SOLUTION BEGIN

The theoretical probability of each pair being chosen is 1/9

P(RR) = 1/9P(RY) = 1/9P(RB) = 1/9

P(YR) = 1/9P(YY) = 1/9P(YB) = 1/9

P(BR) = 1/9P(BY) = 1/9P(BB) = 1/9
• Brelynn and Akimi each make a prediction about the color combination before choosing a block from each bag. Does each person have an equal chance of winning the prize? Explain.

Akimi

I predict 2 reds.

Brelynn

I predict 1 blue and 1 red or 1 blue and 1 red.

SOLUTION BEGIN

P(RR) = 1/9P(BR or RB) = 2/9

Each contestant has a chance of winning the bonus prize.

Brelynn has a better chance than Akimi.

And, each contestant is more likely to lose than to win.

Akimi has an 8/9 chance of losing. Brelynn has an 7/9 chance of losing.
